newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel ups defence spending by $91 million.
newsitem.headline: Israel ups defence spending by $91 million.

text.p: Israel has allocated an additional 300 million shekels ($91 million) for military spending less than a month after setting its 1997 state budget, an official said on Thursday.

"The ministerial committee approved an additional 300 million shekels for stockpiles and supplies," said defence ministry spokesman Avi Benayahu. He said the defence ministry had asked for the additional funds "for the sake of preparedness".
The extra spending was approved on Wednesday by the ministerial security committee.
Israel's parliament approved the government's 190 billion shekel 1997 budget earlier this month after a battle over seven billion shekels in spending cuts, higher taxes and higher fees.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the cuts were necessary to rein-in the deficit.
The 30.4 billion shekels allotted for military spending -- 16 percent of the total budget -- was a slight rise over last year's figure.
The Haaretz newspaper said on Thursday defence officials had asked ministers to approve a three billion shekel ($910 million) increase in spending to deal with the threat of war with Syria.
Defence officials could not immediately comment on the Haaretz report.

With peace talks between the two countries stalled for nearly a year, Israeli military officials and analysts have warned Syria could launch an attack on the Jewish state to break the diplomatic deadlock.
Tensions between the arch-foes soared in September when Syria moved thousands of its troops stationed in Lebanon to within striking range of Israeli positions on the Golan Heights.
Damascus said the redeployment was defensive but some Israeli officials saw it as a prelude to war.
Israel and Syria began peace talks in 1991 after fighting several wars but have failed to agree in sporadic negotiations on a formula to solve their dispute.
The United States is trying to revive the talks which Israel's previous government cut off after a wave of Islamist suicide attacks last year.
Syria demands the return of the Golan Heights which Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East war. Netanyahu also wants all of the strategic plateau.
